moves.1. e4 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 g6 4. Nf3 Bg7: Not a normal opening for me, but fairly standard looking development.
moves.8... e5 9. d5 Ne7: This seems a bad exchange for black, as the g7 bishop seems to have no control any more.
moves.10. h3 Bd7 11. Nh2: Now trying to build up a kingside attack whilst my pieces seem to have good positioning.
moves.11... c6 12. a4:
Erm, yes, like I said, my kingside attack ... :S

Not quite sure why the change of plan here -- I think I was blocking bishop advances to b5 whilst hoping to play Ra3 to get the Rook into kingside play.
moves.12... cxd5 13. exd5 Nf5: Hmmm, not so good. now e4 can release the black bishop and I'm under attack myself. I'd love to know what I should have done differently? The only thing I can think of is playing dxc6 myself and then following with f3, but it seems to restrict the kingside I was trying to activate.
moves.14. Bg5 h6 15. Bxf6 Bxf6 16. Ne4: Trying to maintain the initiative and swap a bishop back as I get uncomfortable with my opponent having both bishops.
moves.16... Kh7: Strange move to me? I'd love to know the thoughts behind this one.
moves.17. Nxf6+: Tempted with g4 and Nxd6, but my desire to remove a bishop was greater.
moves.17... Qxf6 18. Ng4 Qg7 19. Ne3 Qf6 20. N: Kingside pressure is far bigger for black now, so I play for repetition.
moves.24. Qd3 Bf5 25. Qb3: Forced, but happy with this, I had hoped black would play this so I could play Bd3 and swap off more pieces. I've already lost the belief in the win here, which cannot be a good sign.
moves.25... b6 26. Qb4: Single piece threat to the pawn, getting desperate.
moves.26... Qf6 27. Qa3: Hoping to play b4 and lock up the queenside.
moves.28. Bd3: This seems desperate now, as e4 puts so much pressure on white -- Rae8 makes things a lot worse as well.
moves.28... Bxd3: Seems to be a small respite for white now!
moves.29. Qxd3+ Qf5 30. Qxf5+:
Now a draw seems guaranteed after Rxf5 and f3.

Game annotation for team benefit --
